questions.question: 1. Which mathematical property of the Fourier Transform explains why time-domain convolution corresponds to frequency-domain multiplication?

explanations.a: This is incorrect. Linearity refers to the superposition property of the transform.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Duality relates time and frequency domain roles but not convolution directly.
explanations.c: Correct! The Convolution Theorem states that convolution in time is multiplication in frequency.
explanations.d: This is incorrect. Time-shifting affects the phase of the Fourier Transform.

questions.question: 2. What effect does time reversal have on the Fourier Transform of a signal x(t)?

answers.a: It results in a phase shift.
answers.b: It produces the complex conjugate of the Fourier Transform.
answers.c: It reflects the Fourier Transform about the origin.
answers.d: It shifts the Fourier Transform by a constant frequency.

explanations.a: This is incorrect; time reversal doesn't introduce a phase shift.
explanations.b: Incorrect; complex conjugation occurs under different transformations.
explanations.c: Correct! Time reversal reflects the Fourier Transform about the origin.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; time reversal does not shift the spectrum.

questions.question: 3. If x(t) is real and even, what is the nature of its Fourier Transform X(f)?

explanations.a: This is incorrect; real and even signals produce real and even transforms.
explanations.b: Correct! The Fourier Transform of a real and even function is also real and even.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; oddness does not result from even time signals.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; the transform is even, not odd.

questions.question: 4. Why does a rectangular window in the time domain lead to spectral leakage in the frequency domain?

answers.a: Because the Fourier Transform of a rectangular function is a Gaussian.
answers.b: Because the time-domain window is not smooth, causing sinc-like ripples in frequency.
answers.c: Because the rectangular window causes frequency-domain aliasing.
answers.d: Because it increases the resolution in the frequency domain.

explanations.a: This is incorrect; the Fourier Transform of a rectangle is a sinc, not Gaussian.
explanations.b: Correct! Abrupt truncation in time causes spreading in frequency, resulting in spectral leakage.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; aliasing is a sampling issue, not a windowing effect.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; rectangular windows decrease frequency resolution due to leakage.

questions.question: 5. Which of the following is a necessary condition for a signal to have a Fourier Transform?

answers.c: The signal must be absolutely integrable.
answers.d: The signal must have finite bandwidth.

explanations.a: This is incorrect; non-periodic signals can also have Fourier Transforms.
explanations.b: This is incorrect; complex-valued signals can also have Fourier Transforms.
explanations.c: Correct! A necessary condition is that the signal be absolutely integrable.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; finite bandwidth is not a requirement for existence.

questions.question: 6. What is the relationship between the bandwidth of a signal and the width of its Fourier Transform?

answers.a: The bandwidth is inversely proportional to the width of the Fourier Transform.
answers.b: The bandwidth is directly proportional to the width of the Fourier Transform.
answers.c: The bandwidth is unaffected by the Fourier Transform.
answers.d: The bandwidth is related to the phase spectrum of the Fourier Transform.

explanations.a: This is incorrect. The relationship is direct, not inverse.
explanations.b: Correct! The bandwidth of a signal is directly proportional to the width of its Fourier Transform.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; the Fourier Transform affects the bandwidth of the signal.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; the bandwidth is related to the magnitude spectrum, not the phase.

questions.question: 7. What is the Fourier Transform of a triangular pulse?

explanations.a: Incorrect! The Fourier Transform of a rectangular pulse results in a sinc function.
explanations.b: This is incorrect; Gaussian functions are not related to triangular pulses.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; the Fourier Transform of a triangular pulse is not another triangular pulse.
explanations.d: This is correct; the Fourier Transform of a triangular pulse is a sinc function squared.

questions.question: 8. What is the effect of frequency scaling on the Fourier Transform of a signal?

answers.a: The Fourier Transform is scaled by the same factor.
answers.b: The Fourier Transform is scaled by the reciprocal of the scaling factor.
answers.c: The Fourier Transform is shifted in frequency by the scaling factor.

explanations.a: This is incorrect; the scaling in the frequency domain is not straightforward.
explanations.b: Correct! Frequency scaling in the time domain results in an inverse scaling in the Fourier domain.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; frequency scaling does not shift the Fourier Transform.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; scaling in the time domain affects the Fourier Transform.

questions.question: 9. What is the Fourier Transform of a signal x(t) sampled at a rate fs?

answers.a: The Fourier Transform is periodic with period fs.
answers.b: The Fourier Transform is continuous with no periodicity.
answers.c: The Fourier Transform has a frequency shift by fs.
answers.d: The Fourier Transform is a sinc function.

explanations.a: Correct! The Fourier Transform of a sampled signal is periodic with a period equal to the sampling rate fs.
explanations.b: This is incorrect; the Fourier Transform of a sampled signal is periodic.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; there is no frequency shift by fs.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; the Fourier Transform is not necessarily a sinc function.

questions.question: 10. What happens to the Fourier Transform of a signal when the signal is convolved with a filter in the time domain?

answers.a: The Fourier Transform of the signal is multiplied by the Fourier Transform of the filter.
answers.b: The Fourier Transform of the signal is shifted in frequency.
answers.c: The Fourier Transform is unaffected by convolution.
answers.d: The Fourier Transform of the signal is convolved with the Fourier Transform of the filter.

explanations.a: Correct! Convolution in the time domain corresponds to multiplication in the frequency domain.
explanations.b: This is incorrect; convolution in the time domain does not cause a frequency shift.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; convolution in the time domain does affect the Fourier Transform.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; multiplication in the frequency domain corresponds to convolution in the time domain.
